instruction: What metric was chosen to measure the burned areas, and how far can this metric go in understanding fire regimes in Brazil?
Output:
The metric chosen to measure the burned areas in Brazil was the Normalized Burn Ratio (NBR). This metric is derived from spectral data collected by Landsat satellites, specifically the red (RED), near-infrared (NIR), shortwave infrared-1 (SWIR-1), and shortwave infrared-2 (SWIR-2) bands. The minimum NBR values were used to identify burned areas.

This metric can provide valuable information about the extent and frequency of burned areas in Brazil. By analyzing the annual dataset of burned areas, researchers were able to determine that 19.6% of the Brazilian territory was burned from 1985 to 2020, with 61% of this area burned at least once. Additionally, the dataset revealed that most of the burning (83%) occurred between July and October, and the Amazon and Cerrado biomes accounted for 85% of the area burned at least once.

While the NBR metric provides insights into the spatial and temporal dynamics of fire regimes in Brazil, it is important to note that it does not capture all aspects of fire behavior and ecological impacts. Other factors such as fire intensity, severity, and ecological consequences may require additional metrics and data sources for a comprehensive understanding of fire regimes.

instruction: How did the researchers use machine learning models to develop a large-scale time-series of burned areas in Brazil from 1985 to 2020?
Output: The researchers used a machine-learning algorithm to map monthly burned areas in Brazil from 1985 to 2020. They utilized Landsat-based annual quality mosaics retrieved from minimum NBR (Normalized Burn Ratio) values. These annual mosaics integrated spectral data from various bands (RED, NIR, SWIR-1, and SWIR-2) of burned and unburned areas throughout the year. The integrated data was then used to train a Deep Neural Network model. This model was able to generate annual maps of areas burned by land use type for all six Brazilian biomes. The researchers also used the date on which the minimum NBR was captured in a year to reconstruct 36 years of monthly burned area. This approach allowed them to overcome the challenges associated with mapping fire-affected areas and produce a large-scale time-series dataset of burned areas in Brazil.
